clean_story:
Smallest measurable length. Quantum gravity’s limit.


The name comes from Max Planck, who first proposed it in 1899—it’s the tiniest distance where physics still makes sense.


Imagine a ruler so precise that if you tried to measure anything smaller, the act of measuring would warp space itself.
That’s the Planck length: 1. 6 x 10⁻³⁵ meters—a billionth of a trillionth of a trillionth of a centimeter.
At this scale, gravity behaves like a pixelated storm, not a smooth force.
It’s where Einstein’s relativity and quantum mechanics clash, like two maps overlapping but refusing to align.
If you zoomed in on a grain of sand to the Planck length, it would stretch farther than the observable universe.
Black holes, the Big Bang—these extremes brush against this boundary.
Beyond it? Unknown.
Quantum foam.
String theory.
The edge of physics.
